CEN 3078 – Computer Security
Module 1 – Application and Network Analysis – Part 2

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
Module Overview
• Application Layer Protocols
• Secure Communications
• Web Security Concepts
• Email Security
• Firewalls and Intrusion Detection
• Hands-on Labs

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
Application Layer Overview
• Highest layer in the OSI and TCP/IP models
• Provides services for user applications
• Protocols: HTTP, FTP, SMTP, DNS, DHCP, SNMP, etc.

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
HTTP (Hypertext Transfer Protocol)
• Primary protocol for web communication
• Operates on port 80 (HTTP) and port 443 (HTTPS)
• Stateless client-server model
• Uses request and response messages

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
Common HTTP Methods
GET – Request data from a resource
POST – Submit data to be processed
PUT – Replace a resource
DELETE – Remove a resource
HEAD – Retrieve headers only
OPTIONS – Request communication options

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
HTTP Status Codes
1xx – Informational
2xx – Success
3xx – Redirection
4xx – Client error (404 Not Found)
5xx – Server error (500 Internal Server Error)

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
Secure HTTP (HTTPS)
• HTTP over TLS/SSL (Transport Layer Security)
• Encrypts communication between browser and server
• Protects confidentiality and integrity of transmitted data

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
DNS (Domain Name System)
• Resolves human-readable names into IP addresses
• Hierarchical and distributed database
• Uses UDP port 53 for queries
• Vulnerabilities: DNS spoofing and cache poisoning

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
FTP (File Transfer Protocol)
• Used for transferring files between hosts
• Operates on ports 20 (data) and 21 (control)
• Sends data in plaintext — insecure
• FTPS or SFTP preferred for secure transfers

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol)
• Used for sending email between servers
• Operates on port 25
• POP3 and IMAP used for retrieving messages
• Email security extensions include STARTTLS and S/MIME

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
Email Security Threats
• Phishing and spoofing
• Spam and malware attachments
• Man-in-the-Middle attacks
• Compromised credentials
• Lack of encryption

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
Secure Email Technologies
• S/MIME – Secure/Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions
• PGP – Pretty Good Privacy
• Encrypts email contents and verifies sender identity
• Uses public/private key pairs

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
Web Security Threats
• Cross-site scripting (XSS)
• SQL injection
• Cross-site request forgery (CSRF)
• Session hijacking
• Insecure cookies or authentication tokens

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
Web Application Security Controls
• Input validation
• Output encoding
• Proper session handling
• Strong authentication and authorization
• Web Application Firewalls (WAFs)

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
Transport Layer Security (TLS)
• Successor to SSL
• Provides encryption, integrity, and authentication
• Uses asymmetric and symmetric cryptography
• Commonly used in HTTPS, SMTP, IMAP, and VPNs

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
TLS Handshake Overview
1. ClientHello – supported ciphers and versions
2. ServerHello – chooses cipher suite
3. Certificate – server identity
4. Key Exchange – session key established
5. Encrypted communication begins

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
Public Key Infrastructure (PKI)
• Framework for managing digital certificates
• Certificate Authority (CA) issues and signs certificates
• Ensures authenticity and trust in communication

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
Firewalls
• Filter incoming and outgoing network traffic
• Enforce security policies
• Types: Packet-filtering, Stateful, Proxy, Next-Gen
• Key function in network perimeter defense

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
Firewall Rules Example
Allow: TCP port 443 from internal to external
Block: All inbound except established connections
Allow: DNS (UDP 53)
Drop: Unknown or suspicious ports

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS)
• Detect malicious or suspicious activity
• Signature-based and anomaly-based detection
• Examples: Snort, Suricata, OSSEC
• Complements firewall protection

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
Intrusion Prevention Systems (IPS)
• Actively block detected attacks
• Often integrated with firewalls
• Can drop packets, reset sessions, or quarantine hosts

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
Security Information and Event Management (SIEM)
• Aggregates and correlates logs from multiple systems
• Provides real-time analysis and alerts
• Examples: Splunk, IBM QRadar, Elastic Security

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
Network Address Translation (NAT)
• Hides internal IP addresses behind a public IP
• Provides basic security and conserves IPv4 addresses
• Types: Static NAT, Dynamic NAT, Port Address Translation (PAT)

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
Virtual Private Networks (VPNs)
• Securely connect remote users to a private network
• Encrypts traffic over untrusted networks
• Types: Site-to-site, Remote-access
• Common protocols: IPSec, SSL/TLS, WireGuard

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
IPSec Overview
• Operates at the Network Layer
• Provides confidentiality, integrity, and authentication
• Two modes: Transport (end-to-end) and Tunnel (gateway-to-gateway)
• Uses AH and ESP protocols

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
IPSec Architecture
• Authentication Header (AH): integrity and authentication
• Encapsulating Security Payload (ESP): encryption and integrity
• Security Associations (SAs): define connection parameters

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
Secure Shell (SSH)
• Provides secure remote access over TCP port 22
• Replaces insecure protocols (Telnet, rlogin)
• Supports tunneling and port forwarding
• Uses public key authentication

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
Remote Administration Best Practices
• Disable unused remote access protocols
• Use multi-factor authentication (MFA)
• Restrict IP ranges
• Log and monitor all access attempts

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
Network Segmentation
• Divides network into smaller subnets
• Limits attack propagation
• Common approaches: VLANs, firewalls, SDN policies

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
Demilitarized Zone (DMZ)
• Perimeter network separating internal LAN from external traffic
• Hosts public-facing services (web, mail, DNS)
• Protected by firewalls on both sides

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
Load Balancers
• Distribute network or application traffic across servers
• Improve reliability and performance
• Can perform health checks and failover
• Often integrated with reverse proxies

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
Proxy Servers
• Intermediary between clients and servers
• Cache content and mask internal clients
• Types: Forward proxy, Reverse proxy, Transparent proxy

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
Content Delivery Networks (CDNs)
• Distributed servers deliver web content closer to users
• Reduces latency and load
• Adds DDoS protection and caching
• Examples: Cloudflare, Akamai, AWS CloudFront

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
Cloud Security Basics
• Shared responsibility model
• Common risks: misconfiguration, data breaches, API abuse
• Controls: encryption, IAM policies, monitoring, zero-trust design

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
Zero Trust Architecture (ZTA)
• Assume no implicit trust — verify every request
• Enforce least privilege
• Continuous authentication and authorization
• Microsegmentation and strong identity controls

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
Wireless Security
• WPA3 encryption standard
• Disable WPS and default credentials
• Separate guest networks
• Use strong passphrases and 802.1X authentication

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
IoT Security Challenges
• Limited device resources
• Default credentials and weak patching
• Privacy risks and lateral movement
• Solutions: network isolation, firmware updates, strong authentication

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
Incident Response Process
1. Preparation
2. Identification
3. Containment
4. Eradication
5. Recovery
6. Lessons Learned

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
Security Policies and Standards
• Define organizational rules and expectations
• Align with frameworks: NIST, ISO 27001, CIS Controls
• Include acceptable use, password, and incident response policies

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
Security Awareness and Training
• Human error = major attack vector
• Train employees on phishing, password hygiene, reporting
• Conduct regular simulated attacks

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
Review Questions
1. What are the functions of a firewall and IDS?
2. How does TLS secure communications?
3. Explain the purpose of a DMZ.
4. What are common web security threats?

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document:
Summary
• Application protocols introduce specific security challenges
• Network defenses include firewalls, IDS/IPS, VPNs
• Security must be layered and continuously monitored

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 2.pptx

document: End of Module 1 – Part 2
